meta.name: Cadencia Curriculum
meta.description: Evidence-based behavioral training curriculum adapted from PCIT and Incredible Years

phases.name: Fundamentum
phases.subtitle: Foundation
phases.description: Building the relationship foundation through child-directed interaction

lessons.title: Initium
lessons.subtitle: The Beginning
lessons.description: Introduction to Praxia and the science of connection
objectives: Understand the purpose of special time

custosContent.briefing: This lesson introduces the core philosophy: following your child's lead builds trust and reduces power struggles. Research shows 10-15 minutes of daily child-directed play significantly reduces oppositional behavior.
keyPoints: Let your child choose the activity
Your role is to follow, not lead
No teaching, questioning, or correcting during special time
Focus on being present and attentive

filiusContent.title: Welcome to Praxia!
filiusContent.message: This is your special place to learn cool skills and have fun with your family.

custosContent.briefing: Labeled praise tells your child exactly what they did well. Instead of 'Good job!' say 'I love how carefully you stacked those blocks!' This builds specific positive behaviors.
keyPoints: Name the specific behavior you're praising
Be genuine and enthusiastic
Praise effort and process, not just outcomes
Aim for 10+ labeled praises per session
examples: I love how gently you're being with that toy.
You're being so patient waiting for your turn!
Great job using your words to tell me what you need.
I can see you're really concentrating on that.

filiusContent.title: Super Star Words
filiusContent.message: Learn what makes you feel awesome when someone notices what you did!

assignment.description: Use 10 labeled praises during special time

lessons.title: Speculum
lessons.subtitle: The Mirror
lessons.description: Reflecting your child's words back to them
objectives: Learn to reflect feelings, not just words

custosContent.briefing: Reflection shows you're truly listening. When your child says 'Look at my tower!' respond with 'You built a tall tower!' This validates their experience and encourages more communication.
keyPoints: Repeat or paraphrase what they say
Match their emotional tone
Reflect feelings when you notice them
Avoid adding questions or corrections
examples: Child: 'I made it blue!' â†’ You: 'You chose blue for that one.'
Child: 'This is hard!' â†’ You: 'This part is tricky.'
Child: 'Look what I did!' â†’ You: 'You did that all by yourself!'

filiusContent.title: Echo Game
filiusContent.message: When someone really listens, they can say back what you said!

lessons.title: Imago
lessons.subtitle: The Image
lessons.description: Following your child's play by imitating their actions
objectives: Learn to follow rather than lead

custosContent.briefing: Imitation is the highest form of flattery. When you copy your child's play, you communicate 'What you're doing matters.' This shifts the power dynamic and reduces defiance.
keyPoints: Do what they do, with your own materials
Stay slightly behindâ€”don't take over
Narrate that you're copying them
Let them notice and enjoy your imitation
examples: If they stack blocks, you stack blocks nearby
If they draw circles, you draw circles too
If they make car sounds, you make car sounds

filiusContent.title: Copy Cat
filiusContent.message: It's fun when someone plays the same way you do!

assignment.description: Imitate your child's play 5 times during special time

lessons.title: Narratio
lessons.subtitle: The Narration
lessons.description: Describing your child's actions like a sportscaster

custosContent.briefing: Behavioral description is like being a sportscaster for your child's play. 'You're putting the red block on top of the blue one.' This shows attention without evaluation.
keyPoints: Describe actions, not judgments
Use present tense ('You're putting...')
Keep it simple and accurate
This shows you're paying attention
examples: Now you're making them walk together.
commonMistakes: Adding evaluations ('You're drawing a beautiful circle')

filiusContent.title: Play-by-Play
filiusContent.message: Imagine someone is telling the story of what you're doing right now!

assignment.description: Use 10 behavioral descriptions during special time

lessons.title: Gaudium
lessons.subtitle: The Joy
objectives: Understand the power of your genuine presence

custosContent.briefing: Children detect fake enthusiasm instantly. True enjoymentâ€”being present, smiling genuinely, showing interestâ€”communicates 'I want to be here with you.' This is the heart of PRIDE.
keyPoints: Put away distractions (phone!)
Get on their physical level
Make eye contact and smile
Let yourself be curious about their play

filiusContent.title: Happy Together
filiusContent.message: The best times are when everyone is really there and having fun!

assignment.description: Complete a full PRIDE session with all 5 skills

lessons.title: Synthesis I
lessons.subtitle: Bringing It Together
lessons.description: Integrating all PRIDE skills in practice
objectives: Use all PRIDE skills in one session
Identify personal strengths and growth areas

custosContent.briefing: Now we bring it all together. A full PRIDE session flows naturally between skills. Don't force itâ€”let the interaction guide which skill to use. The goal is 10 praises, 10 reflections, 10 descriptions per session.
keyPoints: PRIDE skills work together, not separately
Quality matters more than hitting exact numbers
Notice which skills feel natural vs. challenging
Review your session data to track progress

filiusContent.title: Super Session
filiusContent.message: Let's have the best special time ever!

assignment.description: Complete 3 consecutive PRIDE sessions meeting skill targets

phases.name: Praxis
phases.subtitle: Practice
phases.description: Deepening skills and introducing emotion regulation

custosContent.briefing: Children need words for their feelings before they can manage them. Moving beyond 'mad' and 'sad' to 'frustrated,' 'disappointed,' 'overwhelmed' gives them precision tools.
keyPoints: Teach feeling words during calm moments
Use the thermometer to gauge intensity
Notice body signals (tight fists, fast heart)
Model naming your own emotions

filiusContent.title: Feeling Words
filiusContent.message: There are so many words for how we feel inside!

assignment.description: Complete 5 emotion check-ins using the thermometer

lessons.title: Respiro I
lessons.subtitle: The Breath
lessons.description: Introduction to the Respiro calming protocol

custosContent.briefing: Respiro is our adaptation of the Turtle Technique. The 5 stepsâ€”Halt, Retreat, Breathe, Reflect, Resolveâ€”give a structured path from escalation to calm. Practice during calm moments first.
keyPoints: HALT: Stop all action, freeze
RETREAT: Create space, lower stimulation
BREATHE: 4-count in, 4-count out
REFLECT: Name the feeling and need
RESOLVE: Choose the next small step
practiceInstructions: Practice when calm, not during escalation
Make it a game at first
Use the Gradus visual to track steps

filiusContent.title: Calm Down Steps
filiusContent.message: When big feelings come, we have special steps to feel better!

assignment.description: Practice Respiro together 3 times during calm moments

custosContent.briefing: Now we deepen the breathing practice and add cognitive tools. The 4-7-8 breath activates the parasympathetic nervous system. Personal mantras give the mind something to hold onto.
keyPoints: 4-7-8 breathing: 4 in, 7 hold, 8 out
Help child create their own calming phrase
Identify physical calm-down tools (squeeze ball, etc.)
Create a designated 'calm spot' at home

filiusContent.title: My Calm Words
filiusContent.message: Create your own special words that help you feel better!

assignment.description: Practice 4-7-8 breathing 3 times and create a calming phrase

lessons.title: Praemonitio
lessons.subtitle: The Early Warning
lessons.description: Recognizing escalation signals and intervening early

custosContent.briefing: Early intervention is key. Learn your child's specific signals (clenched fists, raised voice, pacing) and prompt before escalation peaks. 'I notice your body is getting tense. Let's breathe together.'
keyPoints: Every child has unique warning signs
Intervene at level 4-5, not level 8
Use calm, neutral prompts
Offer choices, not commands
prompts: I notice your body is getting tense.
Looks like you might need a break.
Want to try some breaths together?
Should we use our calm-down steps?

filiusContent.title: Body Signals
filiusContent.message: Your body gives you clues when big feelings are coming!

assignment.description: Identify 3 early warning signs unique to your child

lessons.title: Synthesis II
lessons.subtitle: Integration Practice
lessons.description: Combining PRIDE skills with emotion regulation
objectives: Flow between relationship skills and calming skills

custosContent.briefing: Now we integrate everything. During special time, if mild frustration arises, you can model emotion labeling and offer co-regulation while maintaining the PRIDE approach. These skills support each other.
keyPoints: PRIDE builds the relationship foundation
Strong relationships make regulation easier
Use natural moments to practice skills
Keep practicing even when things are going well

filiusContent.title: Putting It Together
filiusContent.message: We've learned so much! Let's use all our skills!

assignment.description: Complete 3 sessions integrating PRIDE and Respiro

custosContent.briefing: After building a strong PRIDE foundation, we can now give effective commands. Direct commands are clear, specific, and stated positively. 'Please put the toys in the bin' not 'Can you maybe clean up?'
keyPoints: Use direct, specific language
State what TO do, not what NOT to do
Give one command at a time
Wait 5 seconds for compliance
Praise compliance immediately

examples.indirect: Would you like to come to dinner now?
examples.direct: Please come to the dinner table now.

filiusContent.title: Clear Directions
filiusContent.message: Sometimes grown-ups need to tell us what to do. Here's how it works!

assignment.description: Practice 5 direct commands with immediate praise for compliance

phases.name: Autonomia
phases.subtitle: Independence
phases.description: Building lasting self-regulation and family harmony
objectives: Transfer skills to child's independent use
